coredata.dc:title: Induced contributions in the depolarized Rayleigh bands of water vapour
coredata.dc:creator: De Santis, A.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Rayleigh spectra of water vapour along the liquid-vapour coexistence curve are investigated. It is shown that the band observed at low frequency (0–70 cm−1) is caused by induced effects. Dipole-induced-dipole (DID) contributions are evaluated in the low-density limit and compared with experimental data.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 147, number 4 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 10 June 1988 INDUCED CONTRIBUTIONS IN THE DEPOLARIZED RAYLEIGH BANDS OF WATER VAPOUR A. DE SANTIS Facolta di Agraria, Universita della Tuscia, via Riello, 01100 Vilerbo, Italy Received 19 January 1988; in final form 5April1988 Rayleigh spectra of water vapour along the liquid vapour coexistence curve are investigated. It is shown that the band observed at low frequency (0 70 cm ) is caused by induced effects. Dipole induced-dipole (DID) contributions are evaluated in the low-density limit and compared with experimental data. 1. Introduction Rayleigh spectra of simple fluids have been widely investigated in recent years. The important role of the dipole induced-dipole (DID) scattering mech- anism has been recognized in fluids of linear mole- cules [1 8]; moreover higher-order polarizabilities and/or atomic site polarizability models can be im- portant in fluids of elongated [6 81 and globular molecules [8 10]. Recent studies on liquid I-125 [11 14] and liquid water [15 18] have demon- strated that first-order DID contributions are more important than rotational allowed contributions in the low-frequency region of depolarized Rayleigh spectra. Isotropic spectra have also been derived and interpreted in terms of higher-order DID and higher- order polarizability contributions [11 18]. In this case, the induction mechanism involves third-rank tensors, that is, the first hyperpolarizability II and the dipole quadrupole polarizability A. The interaction between these molecular properties and the perma- nent dipole and quadrupole moments of surround- ing molecules is the origin of the induced dipole responsible for light scattering. In this work new results on the depolarized Ray- leigh bands of water vapour are reported. Our aim is to give a physical interpretation for the band ob- served in the spectral region O 70 cm 1. Such a band was not noticed in previous experimental work per- formed at very low density [19] and, to our knowl- edge, is observed and treated for the first time in the present study. The Q branch of the y1 band has also been measured and used as an internal standard to obtain relative intensities. Low-density calculations, based on available interaction potential models for water, are performed and theoretical estimates of the DID-induced effects are reported. 2. Experimental The experimental apparatus was a fairly conven- tional laser Raman apparatus (University of Ven- ice) extensively described in previous papers [1,2,14]. The sample of water was of high purity, doubly distilled, deionized and dust free. A brass cell with fused quartz windows and teflon gaskets was used in the first run of measurements. The surpris- ingly high reactivity of water vapour caused strong alteration of the quartz window surfaces at temper- atures over 200 C and prevented reliable measure- ments over 180 C. A cylindrical glass vessel has also been used to check the dependence of the measured spectra on the vessel material. Temperatures were controlled within 1 C and the density data were taken from ref. [20]. Thermodynamical states cor- responding to temperatures of 418, 428, 436 and 453 K were investigated. All the spectra were measured in the HV scattering geometry and data handling was performed following the procedure described else- where t 1,2,14]. The detailed-balance principle was used to evaluate anti-Stokes intensities. A low re 332 o 009-26l4/88/$ 03.50 Elscvier Science Publishers B.V. (North-Holland Physics Publishing Division) Volume 147, number 4 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEflERS 10 June 1988 solving power has been generally chosen, firstly be- cause our main concern was the measurement of integrated intensities and secondly in order to min- imize the effects of water vapor reactivity by in- creasing the measurement rate. The uncertainty in the integrated intensity is quite large (more than 30%) owing to the low-frequency extrapolation, the need for background subtraction (see section 3) and the abovementioned experimental difficulties. 3. Results and discussion In fig. 1 the spectrum at T=428 K is shown. Be- yond 70 cm the rotational allowed spectrum is vis- ible, whereas at lower frequencies another band dominates, To calculate the intensity of this band, a constant background (calculated in the spectral re- gion 70 l 00 cm ) has been subtracted in order to roughly account for the rotational contributions at low frequency. In addition, stray light has been ig- nored at low frequency. No evidence for low-fre- quency structure has been found up to 3 cm- in higher-resolution experiments. To obtain relative intensities, the Q branch of the p, band has been measured at various densities along the coexistence curve. The integrated intensities jt vi) reported in fig. 2 have a linear dependence on density. This fact allows the use of this band as an internal standard. Fig. 3 shows relative intensities of the low-frequency Rayleigh bands, obtained from J*J/J(v!) - (1) o I I 0 0.4 0.8 ~ (PARTICLES! M3X i0~) Fig. 2. Integrated intensities of the Q branch of the I band ver- sus density. The dashed line is a manual fit of the data. As is evident, P increases with density, and is there- fore due to induced effects. Theoretical evaluations of such effects are possible since various potential models for water are avail- able [211. For the DID scattering mechanism, the theoretical analogue of eq. The average <R 12> is given by 1.2 1* 1X10) / 1 / I / 0 / I / // r a w T 4 12 8- 4. I / / Ln (I) z R C A e tie 258 388 Fig. 1. Depolarized spectrum of water vapour (natural logarith- mic scale) at T=428 K (p=0.97x 1026 particles/m3). The res- olution is 7.5 cm . The dashed line indicates the low-frequency extrapolation. 1 I / .. / / /.... . I., /. . 0.4~<~ . 0 0.4 0.8 flparticis./m3 ~O26 Fig. 3. Relative integrated intensities of the low-frequency Ray- leigh band (S). Dashed and dotted lines indicate the theoretical predictions of the TIP3P and TIP4P potentials respectively [21]. The dash-dotted line refers to the Lennard-Jones potential [23]. 333 volume 147, number 4 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEflERS 10 June 1988 <R12>= (82)2JR1,2dRl,2 xj g(R,,2, Q,,Q2) dQ, d.Q2, where Q, denotes the set of Euler angles specifying the orientation of molecule 1 with respect to the lab- oratory frame and R,2 is the distance between the centres of mass. At low density, the pair distribution function g(R,,2, Q,, Q2) has been approximated by exp( U/kr), U(R,,2, Q,, 2~) being the interaction potential. The integrals of eq. (3) have been solved using Gauss Legendre integration techniques and exploring about 1 O5 independent pair geometries for each R,,2 distance. The TIP3P, TIP4P [21] and Len- nard-Jones ~ model potentials have been used. The relative integrated intensities calculated at T= 453 K are plotted in fig. 3. It can be seen that the calculated DID intensity is dependent on the potential model and that experimental results are not satisfactorily reproduced. However, the fact that the experimental and theoretical data have the same order of magni- tude leads to the conclusion that the DID scattering mechanism is largely responsible for the low-fre- quency spectrum in water vapour. As far as the Iineshape is concerned, we have found that a single- exponential decay cannot represent the experimental spectra. Beyond about 30cm (see fig. 1), the spec- tral intensity decreases nearly exponentially with a slope of about 20 cm . This value is in agreement with the prediction of the empirical scaling law valid in the case of simple fluids [24]. But, for freqencies lower than 30 cm , the lineshape is modified sig- nificantly indicating a dynamical behaviour more complex than in simple fluids. Extension of the mea- surements to higher temperatures (and densities) and a more complete comparison with model cal- culations are desirable in order to obtain further in- formation on induced effects and on the microscopic dynamics. SI The Lennard-Jones potential parameters were e=2.72 A and e/k= 355 K as suggested by the simple Rowlinson potential for water [23]. D. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Rayleigh spectra of water vapour along the liquid-vapour coexistence curve are investigated. It is shown that the band observed at low frequency (0–70 cm−1) is caused by induced effects. Dipole-induced-dipole (DID) contributions are evaluated in the low-density limit and compared with experimental data.
